text: greetings from elyria ohio a small city
just 30 miles southwest of Cleveland
settled 200 years ago on the banks of
the Black River the village eventually
grew into a bustling city of industry
its many factories produced items large
and small automobile parts and tiny
screws furnaces and stoves even colored
golf balls malaria still has several
large companies but much of its
manufacturing is gone away today malaria
has 55 thousand residents they tend to
vote Democratic about seventy eight
percent are white about sixteen percent
are african-american and about five
percent are Hispanic or Latino
unemployment is just under eight percent
but many jobs are in the service
industry and don't pay well enough to
support a family in fact the poverty
rate has climbed from ten percent to
1982 nearly seventeen percent today
still through good times and bad elyria
always makes sure to polish its gem of a
city park ely square depicted in many
old postcards the square is the place to
be for Flag Day celebrations weddings
and lunchtime sing-alongs on its
northwest corner you'll find a civil war
monument as well as a memorial brick for
every resident who has ever served in
the military there are many bricks
across the street is the Loomis camera
shop a fixture for 62 years but the 91
year old owner is finally closing up
shop though he plans to sell his goods
on ebay nearby is the minuteman temp
agency before dawn every morning you'll
see a crush of people looking for a job
that they hope will somehow become
full-time and facing the park is Donna's
diner where a cup of coffee is a buck
and a half a buck and a quarter with
breakfast
you
